3 Abstract
4
5
6 Objectives. Osteoarthritis (OA) is the most prevalent chronic musculoskeletal disease. Early
7
identification of individuals at risk of knee structural progression is essential for targeted
8
9
interventions. This study aimed to develop and validate a machine/deep learning (ML/DL)-based
10
11 prognostic model for knee OA progression using serum metabolomics.
12
13
Methods. Baseline serum metabolomic factors from two independent cohorts were analyzed:
14
15 Tasmanian Older Adult Cohort (n=180) for model development and Licofelone trial (n=137) for
16
17 external validation. Participants were categorized by likelihood of knee structural progression
18
using MRI and X-ray data. Four metabolomic scenarios were evaluated: metabolites alone (104),
19
20
plus their ratios or inverse ratios (each 5,460), and all combined (10,816), alongside age, sex, BMI.
21
22 Metabolomic profiling used high-throughput omics. Batch effects were corrected via ComBat.
23
24 Feature selection combined variable clustering with elastic net regularization. Top-selected
25
features of each scenario were trained using five ML/DL models, with performance assessed by
26
27
AUC, accuracy, sensitivity, and specificity with 95% confidence intervals.
28
29
Results. The metabolomic-only scenario, including sex and age, yielded the best performance.
30
31
Feature clustering reduced to 22, with the top 10 used for training/testing. The Artificial Neural
32
33 Network with domain-adversarial component outperformed other algorithms with domain shift.
34
35 The final model, including six metabolites (SM (OH) C22:2, proline, citrulline, LysoPC a C18:0,
36
glutamate, and C12-DC), plus sex and age, demonstrated excellent predictive performance (test:
37
38
AUC 0.98[0.95,1], accuracy 0.89[0.84,0.94]; validation: AUC 0.89[0.83,0.95], accuracy
39
40 0.85[0.79,0.91]).
41
42
Conclusion. This validated metabolomics DL framework
43
44 (https://github.com/AFSHINJAM/KOA_Prediction_Metabolomics_Ratios) introduces a novel
45
46 approach for predicting knee OA structural progression, enabling personalized risk assessment and
47
early intervention.
48
49
50 Short title: Prognostic prediction of knee osteoarthritis structural progression using metabolomic-
51
based machine learning.
52
53
54 Keywords: Machine/deep learning; prognostic; metabolomics; knee osteoarthritis; biomarkers,
55
56 risk factors.

4
5 • Our study introduces a metabolomics-based deep learning model predicting structural
6 progression in knee osteoarthritis.
7 • The deep learning model was externally validated, underscoring its generalizability and
8
strengthening its scientific robustness.
9
10 • Our findings reveal novel metabolites associated with structural progression in knee
11 osteoarthritis.

3 Introduction
4
5
6 Osteoarthritis (OA) is a chronic degenerative joint disorder and a leading global cause of disability,
7
8 exerting a growing economic burden on healthcare systems [1, 2]. It manifests as joint pain,
9
10
stiffness, and functional deterioration, harming the quality of life. The knee is often impacted; a
11
12
13 consequence of its critical role in mobility and the considerable mechanical load it bears. OA can
14
15 also lead to emotional strain and social difficulties, amplifying its impact [3, 4].
16
17
Although typically a slow-progressing condition, some OA patients experience rapid structural
18
19
deterioration that leads to severe disease in a relatively short time [5, 6]. Diagnosis usually occurs
20
21
22 after substantial joint damage, limiting opportunities for timely intervention and complicating the
23
24
development of targeted treatment strategies. Current prognostic tools rely heavily on expert
25
26
clinical judgment, introducing subjectivity. These evaluations may be enhanced by imaging
27
28
29 techniques like radiography (X-ray) and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI). Although both
30
31 provide structural insights, with MRI being particularly sensitive to early tissue changes, they are
32
33
often limited by the need for expert interpretation.
34
35
36 To improve early risk identification, researchers are turning to machine (ML)/deep (DL) learning
37
38 approaches combined with circulating biochemical markers to generate data-driven prognostic
39
40
tools. While much of the previous research has concentrated on genomic or proteomic biomarkers,
41
42
metabolomics offers a dynamic and integrative view of both physiological and pathophysiological
43
44
45 states, making it particularly well-suited for monitoring disease progression.
46
47
Metabolites are small molecules and represent the end products of cellular metabolism, providing
48
49
a real-time snapshot of biochemical activity. As downstream indicators of gene and protein
50
51
52 interactions, metabolites respond dynamically to pathological changes, making them valuable for
53
54 disease prediction and prognosis. Although interest in looking for metabolomics in OA has grown
55
56
57
58
59 4
60

3 in recent years [7-13], the potential of a defined metabolomic signature for predicting structural
4
5
progression remains insufficiently explored. Developing metabolite-based markers alongside risk
6
7
8 factors for early detection of knee OA structural progression can markedly improve patient
9
10 stratification and support earlier, targeted interventions.
11
12
We hypothesized that ML/DL models trained on unbiased serum metabolomic data could
13
14
accurately predict individuals at high risk of knee OA structural progression. We aimed to develop
15
16
17 a robust, reproducible, and validated automated predictive framework that combines high-
18
19
throughput metabolomic profiling with advanced ML/DL methodologies. Our ultimate goal is to
20
21
facilitate personalized OA management and promote precision medicine in OA care.
22
23
24
25
26
Methods
27
28
29
This study conforms to the TRIPOD reporting guidelines for prognostic model development [14].
30
31
Sample and Cohort Population
32
33
34 Baseline fasting serum samples were collected and stored at -80ºC. Participants were drawn from
35
36
two independent cohorts: the Tasmanian Older Adult Cohort (TASOAC) [15, 16] and the
37
38
Licofelone clinical trial [17]. For both cohorts, analyses were conducted using the participant’s
39
40
41 target knee.
42
43 The modelling cohort comprised participants from TASOAC, aged 50-80, recruited from the
44
45
electoral roll in southern Tasmania, Australia [15]. A total of 180 participants with available
46
47
48 metabolomics data [18] were included. Ethical approval was obtained from the Southern
49
50 Tasmanian Health and Medical Human Research Ethics Committee.
51
52
For the external validation, samples were from a Phase III clinical randomized, double-blind trial
53
54
comparing Licofelone, a lipoxygenase and cyclo-oxygenase inhibitor, to Naproxen in symptomatic
55
56
57
58

5
with available metabolomics data were included [10, 19]. Ethics approval was granted by a central
6
7
8 review board (IRB Institutional Review Board Services, ON, Canada) and the institutional review
9
10 board of the Centre hospitalier de l’Université de Sherbrooke (QC, Canada).
11
12
All patients provided written informed consent, including permission for serum collection and
13
14
biomarker analysis.
15
16
17 Feature Selection and Predictive Model Development (Figure 1)
18
19
Classification of OA Structural Progressors and Non‑progressors
20
21
22 The outcome was defined as identifying individuals at high risk of structural progression of knee
23
24
OA. Participants were classified as structural progressors or non-progressors using a previously
25
26
described ML algorithm applied to MRI and radiographic data [20-22]. Details are provided in the
27
28
29 Supplementary Methods in Supplementary Data S2.
30
31
Metabolomic Profiling
32
33
TASOAC samples were profiled using two platforms: 59 with Biocrates AbsoluteIDQ® p180 kit
34
35
36 (Biocrates Life Sciences AG, Innsbruck, Austria) and 121 with the Metabolomics Innovation
37
38
Centre (TMIC) Prime Metabolomics Profiling Assay (https://www.metabolomicscentre.ca).
39
40
Licofelone validation cohort samples were analyzed exclusively using the Biocrates
41
42
43 AbsoluteIDQ® p180 kit. A total of 104 metabolites were used, including glycerophospholipids,
44
45 acylcarnitines, amino acids, biogenic amines, and sphingolipids. Details for the profiling protocols
46
47
are in the Supplementary Methods in Supplementary Data S2.
48
49
50 Sample Size Estimation
51
52 Using the MetSizeR package [23], we estimated the sample size needed to control the false
53
54
discovery rate at 0.05, assuming 20% of 104 metabolomic features would show significant

Data Preprocessing and Outlier Detection
11
12
Metabolomic features were log -transformed and standardized. Sparse Principal Component
13 2
14
15 Analysis (sPCA) was used to detect potential outliers, identified as samples exceeding three
16
17 standard deviations from the mean.
18
19
Batch Effect Correction
20
21
22 To address batch effects from different profiling platforms in TASOAC, we applied the
23
24 nonparametric ComBat method, evaluated using Shapiro-Wilk tests and sPCA. A null model
25
26
excluding covariates minimized the risk of confounding effects. The cleaned dataset was used for
27
28
29 all subsequent analyses.
30
31
Feature Selection Scenarios
32
33
We evaluated four feature sets in which the risk factors, age, sex, and body mass index (BMI),
34
35
36 were included in every scenario: 1) metabolites alone (104); 2) metabolites plus ratios (5,460); 3)
37
38 metabolites plus inverse ratios (5,460); 4) metabolites plus both ratios (10,816). Ratios were
39
40
analyzed as proxies for enzymatic activity.
41
42
43 Dimensionality Reduction and Feature Selection
44
45
Feature Clustering. Highly correlated features were grouped using the VarClusHi algorithm
46
47
(https://github.com/jingtt/varclushi; Python implementation). Before clustering, in scenarios 2-4,
48
49
50 low variance features were filtered utilizing dynamic thresholds to reduce noise and computational
51
52 load

8 Predictive Feature Selection. Regularized logistic regression with an elastic net penalty was further
9
10 applied to select the top 10 most predictive features (metabolites plus risk factors) per scenario.
11
12
Features were standardized to prevent scale bias. Absolute regression coefficients ranked feature
13
14
importance.
15
16
17 Machine/Deep Learning Model Development
18
19
Training and Class Imbalance Correction. The dataset was randomly divided into 80% training
20
21
22 and 20% testing, with classification labels determined as described above. To address class
23
24 imbalances in the training data, we applied the Synthetic Minority Over-sampling Technique
25
26
(SMOTE) in each scenario. In our dataset, class imbalance refers to the unequal distribution of
27
28
progressors and non-progressors, with progressors representing 32% (n=57) in TASOAC and 72%
29
30
31 (n=99) in Licofelone. SMOTE generated synthetic progressors to improve model balance.
32
33
Performance was evaluated using the area under the curve (AUC), accuracy (ACC), sensitivity,
34
35
and specificity with their 95% confidence interval (CI) for the optimal model (AUC [24]; other
36
37
38 metrics [25]).
39
40 Model Selection. For the development of the prediction model, we selected the top 10 features
41
42
(metabolites plus risk factors where appropriate) for each scenario. We tested four ML
43
44
45 (Regularized Logistic Regression, Support Vector Machines (SVM), Random Forest, and Extreme
46
47 Gradient Boosting (XGBoost)) models and one DL, Artificial Neural Networks (ANN) model per
48
49
scenario.
50
51
Domain Adaptation. To improve generalizability across cohorts, domain adaptation strategies
52
53
54 were implemented. ML models used sample reweighting based on density ratio estimation (DW).
55

3 For the DL model, a Domain-Adversarial Neural Network (DANN) was implemented in
4

TensorFlow using the top-ranked 10 features. Implementation details are in the Supplementary
6
7
8 Methods in Supplementary Data S2. For the optimal model, we conducted an iterative feature
9
10 selection process, evaluating each model using various feature subsets, ranging from five to ten.
11
12
Feature Interpretation
13
14
15 To interpret model predictions, we employed SHapley Additive exPlanations (SHAP), which
16
17 provide a consistent framework for interpreting model predictions by quantifying each feature’s
18
19
contribution to the prediction. Features were ranked on their absolute SHAP values. SHAP
20
21
22 estimates the marginal impact of each feature on the output by evaluating all possible
23
24 combinations, thereby providing a thorough measure of feature importance. In addition, SHAP
25
26
values indicate the directionality (positive or negative) of each feature's effect on the
27
28
prediction. Further, we generated Partial dependence plots (PDPS), which illustrated how
29
30
31 individual features influence prediction probabilities, offering insights into model behaviour.
32
33
34
35
Results
36
37
38
Baseline Characteristics of Participants
39
40
Table 1 presents baseline characteristics for modelling (TASOAC) and validation (Licofelone)
41
42
43 cohorts. Although the mean age was similar, other characteristics showed statistical differences.
44
45 The validation cohort had fewer males (p=0.008), higher BMI (p≤0.001), and more severe OA,
46
47
reflected by higher Western Ontario and McMaster Universities Osteoarthritis Index (WOMAC)
48
49
50 scores (all p≤0.001), greater joint space narrowing (JSN) (p≤0.001), and reduced joint space width
51
52 (JSW) (p≤0.001).

47
This study introduced an interpretable DL model capable of predicting knee OA structural
48
49
50 progression using a serum metabolomic signature. Publicly available on GitHub
51
52 (https://github.com/AFSHINJAM/KOA_Prediction_Metabolomics_Ratios), the model includes
53
54
six baseline serum metabolites, SM (OH) C22:2, proline, citrulline, LysoPC a C18:0, glutamate,

6
7
8 Among predictors, SM (OH) C22:2 and glutamate were strongly and positively associated with
9
10 OA structural progression, while others demonstrated nonlinear effects, in which intermediate
11
12
values influenced predictions differently than extreme concentrations. Females had a slightly
13
14
higher risk of OA structural progression than males.
15
16
17 Early OA prognosis remains a significant clinical challenge, mainly due to the poor sensitivity of
18
19
current diagnostic methods and the weak symptom-structure correlation [26, 27]. As such,
20
21
investigating upstream molecular changes may provide a more precise prognostic approach [28,
22
23
24 29]. While previous studies have explored some “omics” technologies with OA-related tissue,
25
26 evaluation of serum metabolomic signature specifically for OA structural progression prediction
27
28
remains underexplored. Metabolomics offers a dynamic readout of biochemical activity, serving
29
30
31 as highly dynamic and sensitive indicators of changes related to diseases [30], more particularly
32
33 on joint impairments and cartilage health [31, 32].
34
35
Despite prior studies linking individual metabolites to OA severity [7-13], to our knowledge, none
36
37
have used a ML/DL approach to predict structural progression with high-dimensional metabolic
38
39
40 datasets (10,816 combining metabolites and ratios). Our approach, leveraging high-throughput
41
42
technologies with ML/DL algorithms, enables a fully data-driven selection of relevant predictors,
43
44
identifying non-intuitive metabolic factors that traditional models might overlook.
45
46
47 A key element of our model’s success was integrating domain adaptation into our ML/DL models
48
49 to align latent feature representations between cohorts, addressing dataset distributional shifts
50
51
between the modelling (TASOAC), a community-based cohort with generally milder OA, and the
52
53
54 external (Licofelone) cohorts, which consisted of patients with a more advanced disease. TASOAC

ANNs can capture complex, nonlinear relationships between features, which are often difficult for
13

19

20

than dataset-specific patterns. Third, unlike ML models that interpret feature importance per
22
23
24 sample, ANNs aggregate and leverage multiple feature dependencies simultaneously, making
25
26 them more adaptable across individuals.
27
28
The interpretability of the predictive model, done using SHAP and PDPs, provides insight into
29
30
31 feature behaviour and offers a dynamic story. SHAP captures feature influence per individual,
32
33 while PDPs reveal the average directional impact when varying one feature in isolation.
34
35
SM (OH) C22:2, the top-ranked metabolite, belongs to the sphingolipid family. While its specific
36
37
role in OA remains partially understood, this metabolite is involved in inflammatory regulation,
38
39
40 cell membrane integrity and apoptosis, which contribute to chondrocyte death and synovial
41
42
inflammation, both central mechanisms in OA progression [33-35]. High concentrations were
43
44
associated with increased progression risk, suggesting a lipid dysregulation.
45
46
47 Proline was another strong positive predictor. Its role may seem paradoxical, as proline is a key
48
49 amino acid involved in collagen biosynthesis, which is essential for the structural integrity of
50
51
cartilage. However, its elevated levels in circulation may indicate collagen breakdown, consistent

26 10]. It exhibited an inverted U-shape relationship with OA risk. Moderate elevations may signal

OA progression risk, while extremes could reflect a reduced risk of progression. Low

31 concentrations may signify an inadequate repair signalling and higher levels a shift towards anti-

35
Glutamate, a multifunctional amino acid and traditionally recognized as a neurotransmitter, also
36
37
plays critical roles in nitrogen transport, amino acid biosynthesis, and energy metabolism, all of
38
39

41
42

43

45
46
47 and inflammatory cascades [42, 43]. This appears to occur due to an altered modulation of N-
48
49 methyl-d-aspartic acid receptors, where, in OA, an additional subunit is expressed [42, 44]. Its
50
51

52

Age and sex also played key roles, reinforcing their well-established demographic risk factors in

32
33 increases with age, a plateau or slight decline at advanced ages may reflect reduced sensitivity to
34

The nonlinear effects observed for citrulline, age, LysoPC a C18:0, and C12-DC, highlight the
43
44
limitations of linear models in capturing biological complexity and support the value of DL
45
46
47 frameworks. Moreover, integrating DANN into ANN was instrumental in maintaining consistent
48
49 feature representations across cohorts by dynamically reweighting sample contributions and
50
51
correcting for dataset shifts. Another strength of this study lies in the utilization of two distinct
52
53
54 cohorts spanning a spectrum of OA severity. This improves the model’s clinical relevance and

6
7
8 Importantly, the development of such a predictive model is not intended to replace current clinical
9
10 tools but to complement them. It may enhance clinical decision-making by identifying individuals
11
12
at high risk for progression, enabling early intervention through lifestyle, therapy, or
13
14
pharmacological approaches. Moreover, it has implications for drug development. The historically
15
16
17 low success rates of disease-modifying OA drug trials, often due to low progression prevalence
18
19
(less than 15%) within standard trial periods [51, 52], could be improved through better participant
20
21
stratification using such models.
22
23
24 As with any study, the present work has limitations. First, both cohorts consisted of Caucasian
25
26 participants, limiting generalizability across diverse ethnic populations. Second, the relatively
27
28
small sample size and high-dimensional metabolomic dataset raise concerns about overfitting,
29
30
31 although steps were taken to mitigate this. Third, some identified metabolites lack a well-defined
32
33 biological role in OA, underscoring the need for functional studies.
34
35
In conclusion, our findings show that combining serum metabolomics profiles with demographic
36
37
features in interpretable DL models can provide reliable, individualized prediction of knee OA
38
39
40 structural progression. While further validation and translation into clinical practice are required,
41
42
this approach enhances current understanding in the field and may help identify novel therapeutic
43
44
avenues. Importantly, this work also marks a step toward precision OA management that should
45
46
47 facilitate earlier interventions and more effective therapeutic development, which should help alter
48
49 the course of this highly prevalent and debilitating disease.

C
Background: We examined the association between physical activity (PA) and joint space loss (JSL) over 48 months in individuals
with knee osteoarthritis to assess the role of the PA level in knee osteoarthritis progreIssion.
Methods: We analyzed 1,806 participants from the Osteoarthritis Initiative. PA
T
was measured with the Physical Activity Scale
for the Elderly (PASE) and was categorized as low, moderate, or high. JSL was defined as a reduction in joint space width of
‡0.7 mm. Analyses were stratified by the baseline Kellgren-LawrenRce (KL) grade. Cox proportional-hazards (CoxPH) and
joint models assessed the association between baseline PA and changes in longitudinal PA and JSL, adjusting for
covariates.
Results: Over 48 months, 33.8% of the patients experienced AJSL. In patients with KL grade 2, the moderate PA tertile was
associated with a reduced JSL risk compared with low PA in both standard and marginal CoxPH analyses. However, in patients
with KL grade 3, increasing PA in the continuous PASE modeling was associated with increased JSL risk (marginal CoxPH: hazard
ratio [HR], 1.002 [95% confidence interval (CI), 1.001 to 1.004] ), confirmed by joint models (HR, 1.083 [95% CI, 1.020 to 1.150]). The
rate of change of PA over time did not significantly Sinfluence progression.
Conclusions: Moderate or high PA did not increase the 4-year JSL risk in patients with KL grade 2. However, higher
current PA was associated with higher JSSL risk in patients with KL grade 3, highlighting the need for further research
on the complex impact of PA on osteoarthritis. These fi ndings may help clinicians to identify patient subgroups who
could bene fi t from tailored PA recommendations, informing va lue-based care and personalized osteoarthritis
management. E
Level of Evidence: Prognostic Level III. See Instructions for Authors for a complete description of levels of evidence.
